fields.value: Replication Data for: Technology Diffusion and Productivity Growth in Health Care

dsDescriptionValue.value: Skinner, Jonathan, and Staiger, Douglas, (2015) "Technology Diffusion and Productivity Growth in Health Care." Review of Economics and Statistics 97:5, 951-964.

fields.value:
The SAS program "unified" was the first program used to create an individual-level research database from the primary Medicare claims data. From that basic output file, we then run STATA files (stage 1, stage 2, and stage 3) with ancillary public use data as included.  

The files posted here were used to estimate the theoretical model in "Technology Diffusion and Productivity Growth in Health Care.  They include computer code (SAS and STATA), and publicly available data on income by state and year, hospital-level information, hospital to hospital referral region (HRR) crosswalks, and a dataset on the diffusion of drug-eluting stents by hospital. 

We are not able to post the actual Medicare claims data (including the Cooperative Cardiovascular Project data from 1994/95), because that is protected by strict confidentiality agreements with CMS.  We would be happy to advise any researchers on how to apply for these Medicare claims data.

files.description: The STATA "stage 2" do file that primarily uses the CCP data to create hospital-level measures of "factor 1" and "factor 2" quality.
files.label: stage2_hosp_may2014.do

files.description: The STATA do file for the final (stage 3) regression estimates that integrates the hospital-level data from the CCP with the Medicare claims outcome data, also aggregated to the hospital level.

files.description:
This is the original SAS program from 2007 that created an extract of the Medicare claims data limited to only AMI patients. It was written by Weiping Zhou, and outputs the cohort data (1986-2004) which, after conversion to STATA, is used in the STATA "Step 1" program:

"/jss/Trend/ami/Unified_ami/unified_ami8604.dta",
files.label: unified.docx

dataFile.description:
